text: this recipe is based on a Native
American recipe and it was given to me
by Betty Fussel who's a food writer
she's one of my mentors and she is a
fantastic cook so I have brown sugar
right here I'm gonna add my salt a
little bit of spice just a little bit
I've got mace a little bit of allspice
lemon zest which is actually not part of
Betty's recipe that's my little
adaptation black pepper use a lot of
black pepper you want a little bit of a
bite just stir that up and what the Cure
does is it not only adds flavor but also
the salt helps almost cook the salmon
before I smoked it it firms up the flesh
and it gives it a great texture when you
see that the little bits of lemon zest
are evenly distributed you know you've
got a pretty good mixture you want to
just distribute this evenly on the
salmon you need to do this ahead to give
it a chance to really permeate the flesh
and then also draw out some of the
moisture Betty does it 24 hours ahead
but I found you can actually get away
with four hours
you don't have to worry about getting it
on the skin side but you do want to get
the sides over here just cover this up
and then I'm just gonna stick this in
the fridge in order to get that nice
smoke on the grill what I did was I've
got hickory chips here I soaked them in
water you have to do that about thirty
minutes ahead you drain them and then
I'm gonna put them right on top of these
hot coals and they're gonna smoke up my
grill and they're gonna cook my salmon
should be plenty smoky you just want to
close up this vent maybe crack it just a
little bit but what you want is most of
the smoke to stay inside the grill where
it can flavor the fish so these have
been cured I gave them a quick little
rinse you don't want too much of that
cure on top of the fish it's already
done its job it's permeated it and the
excess will just make it taste too sweet
too salty so I'm just giving this a very
light brushing with olive oil before it
goes on the grill you really want to go
light here because salmon is pretty
fatty on its own and I'm really not
looking for flare-ups I want to keep
that fire where it belongs on the coals
now I'm going to put the salmon knot
right in the center where the grill is
it's very very hottest I'm gonna put it
in a ring around where it's sort of
medium hot too hot they would overcook
before they absorb as much as well cuz I
want them to have and
put them flesh side down you want to
check the fish after about five or six
minutes and this is important if the
fish isn't coming off the grill easily
that means it's not done when it starts
to unstick itself you know that it's
done yeah see how easy it is to turn and
then I'm just gonna let it finish
cooking for another few minutes and it
also crisp up the skin it's gonna check
the fish see if it's done and you can
cook this salmon to taste for this
though I want it to be a little bit dark
pink in the center yeah that's perfect
and these are ready at this point
they're delicate
Betty likes to serve this with a tart
strawberry sauce she has a little bit of
vinegar and it's great but I'm going for
something simpler here lemon wedges do
the trick that's all that's needed to
cut that rich salmon this is a great
recipe Thank You Betty
